TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Euic, isohyperthermic Lithic Udifolists

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Matecumbe muck on a tropical hammock (colors are for moist soil).
Oa--0 to 6 inches; black (10YR 2/1) muck; 15 percent fiber unrubbed and less than 5 percent rubbed; 5 percent by weight of sandy and loamy material; massive; very friable; 30 percent by volume of live roots; 10 percent by volume of limestone fragments less than 3 inches in size; medium acid; abrupt wavy boundary (2 to 9 inches thick).
2R--6 inches; soft to hard but rippable coral bedrock.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Monroe County, Florida; Key Largo; SE 1/4, SE 1/4, SE 1/4, Sec. 23, T. 59 S., R. 40 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Depth to bedrock is 2 to 9 inches.
The Oa horizon has hue of 5YR to 10YR, value of 3 or less, and chroma of 1 or 2,  The soil is muck, mucky peat, or gravelly muck with a mineral content of less than 20 percent.  Percent by volume of gravel size limestone or coral fragments is 5 to 35 percent.  Reaction ranges from medium acid to neutral.
The 2R horizon consists of soft to hard, but rippable coral or oolitic limestone.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Keaukaha, Opihikao, and Punaluu series.  These soils are well drained and do not have a water table within 60 inches and contain volcanic ash

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Matecumbe soils are on tropical hammocks.  Elevations are less than 10 feet above 1929 NGVD.  The mean annual temperature ranges from 74 to 78 degrees F., and the mean annual precipitation ranges from 50 to 65 inches.  Most areas are subject to flooding from hurricanes and tropical storms.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content:
GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the well drained mineral Keyvaca and Pennekamp soils on higher landforms; the
somewhat poorly drained marly Saddlebunch soils on similar to slightly lower landforms; and the poorly drained marly Cudjoe, Keywest, and Lignumvitae soils and very poorly drained organic Islamorada, Keylargo, and Tavernier soils on lower landforms.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  These soils are moderately well drained with a high water table of 1 1/2 to 3 feet during wet periods of most years.  Permeability is rapid.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  This soil is used for recreational and urban development.  Many areas remain in native vegetation of wild tamarind, mahogany, poison wood, wild coffee, crabwood, strangler fig, thatch palm, and paradise tree.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Matecumbe soils are of small known extent on the Florida Keys and Southern Peninsular Florida.  These soils may occur on other tropical islands.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Auburn, Alabama

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Monroe County, Florida, 1989.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
